questions.question_text: A company is implementing a work-from-home policy. As a result, the security team needs to provide guidelines and recommendations to secure such an infrastructure and have more control over users' mobile devices. Which of the following should the security administrator recommend? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
C. BYOD policy
Bring-your-own-device (BYOD) policies are set by companies to allow employees to use their personal smartphones, laptops, and tablets for work
E.MDM policy
mobile device management policy establishes rules for how mobile devices are used and secured within your company.

C. BYOD policy – you can’t assume that workers will use their own equipment. It doesn’t secure the company’s assets as no one has control over what people can install on their devices while accessing corporate data. Everyone can have different phones (brands, models, OS) which complicate security.
E. MDM policy – this lets you push updates, secure devices and manage them from a centralized place. The best model, in this case, is to apply the COPE or CYOD policy model.
F. Time-based login policies – it will restrict people from accessing assets out of hours.
I am going for E and F.

comments.content: Oh great, another Apple user that does not know anything about Android security.

discussion.content: They want more control over mobile devices and they want to be secure. Also it doesn't mention that they are worried about cost. So why is C and answer here? I'd imagine a lot of user's own devices would be android-based phones compromised with malware and the like...

comments.content: Per Professor Messer, I would choose C over F

discussion.content: I would go with E, F because the company is concerned with security of such I frustructure so mdm would help manage and secure mobile devices and restricting off hours login would help secure the data that's being accessed.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is used for building entry and computer access?

comments.content: Key fobs are rarely used for building access, but can be used, however, unless there is a time generated code to access a computer within that same fob, it normally would not double for that purpose. Smartcard is the most correct answer IMO.
Both you and DmiNet are incorrect. Key fobs are often used for building access and there are a lot of access control companies that utilize them, such as HID, Kastle, Datawatch Systems, etc.

discussion.content: Key fobs is not used for building access but Smart Cards can be used for building and computer access.

Once again, this site proves to be a garbage piece of shit with clearly wrong answers. Of course, we can all tell this is true, because this comment is "approved" by a moderator. Absolute horse shit here

comments.content: copy pasta the question in google and you'll see the same answers from multiple like sites

discussion.content: A. Smart card – workstations can be secured with smart cards or fingerprint scanner

Selected Answer: A
The answer is smart cards. I have to use a smart card for building access as well as computer access

Selected Answer: A
The keys are named after the chains that used to contain pocket watches for clothing. Key FOBs are embedded radiofrequency identification circuits (RFID) that fit a key set and are used with physical access control systems. They are desired to be used to access external and internal doors for the bublegos. The key FOBs are close devices of proximity that authorize the user for the entrance; An electronic block is acts, the device is present and the door can be opened. This is an authentication factor of the subjection you have.
Although, the smart card with RFID is also a valid response.
In this case the question is ambiguous.

According to the Mike Meyers book - 'Security tokens are device that store some unique information.....digital certificates, passwords, bio data........Most security hardware tokens coming in the form of key fobs.'

Many enterprise-level businesses use a smart-card system to enable employees to access company resources and display proper credentials so they have proper levels of access too. A smart card reader comes in many forms, from small devices that can attach to a laptop computer (see Figure 10-25) to a panel next to a secure door. The smart card reader scans the chip embedded in such devices as ID badges to enhance access and security.
- Mike Meyers ebook

I think it's either key fobs or smart cards based on what I read on the Mike Meyers ebook, either one could be used... from my military experience, smart cards (CAC cards) were used to enter secure areas and access computers.

According to Get Certified Get Ahead - "A personal identity verification (PIV) card is also a specialized type of smart card used by personnel in United States federal agencies. Just as a CAC does, the PIV card includes a picture of the user along with their name. A PIV can be used for visual verification of users, and then as a smart card when users log onto their computer."

Ok so this caught me off guard. I was thinking smart cards as they can be used for both swiping in and logging into a PC. A fob is not used to log into aka access a computer itself.
But the question doesn't ask that. It asks how you gain access to the physical computer itself and that is hinted to by the fact that building access and gate access can use key fobs all the time as a alternative to a badge reader card/smart card or keys. So the answer is D because it gives us access to the building and then the door to the room with the computer in it. The question is not fair though as it is presumed we want to access the building physically and then the computer access could be logically with a smart card.
Thank God this site is free because these questions/answers are better suited to fertilize my lawn.
Smart cards and PIV Cards are both used for PC and Door Access within the federal government. The answers provided 3/4 are correct
Key fobs are used for buildiing access but can not be used to access computers. Smart Card is the right answer
Personal identity verification card or Smart cards?

A key fob, commonly known as a “fob” is a small security hardware device with a built-in authentication that is used to control and secure access to mobile devices, computer systems, network services, building operations, and secured information. Many key fobs are typically used as access control devices into secured buildings such as doors.

Key fobs are among a class of physical security tokens that includes smart cards, proximity cards and biometric keyless entry fobs. Hardware tokens are usually small enough for individuals to store on a key ring, in their wallet, pockets, and jackets.

Computational performance of smart cards is often rather limited because of extreme low power consumption and ultra-thin form-factor requirements.

comments.content: After more consideration, PIV is most correct (being a standard in some countries governments) although it is still only a specific form Smart Card. PIV have credentials stored on them for PC and network access among other things. Again, they are just a specific usage of a Smart Card though.

discussion.content: Smart Card is correct. Some keyboards have built-in smart card readers for this purpose.
should be PIV although PIV is a form of smart card aswell. silly answers...
I think it should be smart card
Key fobs are RFID and so would really be the only option out of the 4 that could be used for both door and pc

comments.content: Smart Cards are also RFID, same goes for their PIV subset.

discussion.content: "Personal identity verification card". I hope they'll correct it on this site
Personal identity verification card
Yes, answer is Smartcard

questions.question_text: A user updated an iOS smartphone and is now having issues connecting to the Internet. The phone shows 1x for signal strength while making calls. Which of the following are the MOST likely causes of these issues? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
baseband better answer?

C. No wireless connectivity – it is possible that the user’s location can be an issue of the weak signal
D. Baseband – the OS update could also update the firmware, which could change the PRI and PRL. Information that the cellular radio needs to connect to the network is provided as Preferred Roaming Index (PRI) and Preferred Roaming List (PRL) databases.

"1x for signal strength" pertains to cellular signal and implies WiFi is either disabled or is not being utilized. 1x is also one of the lowest cellular signal strength measurements, which is why 'slow data speeds' is the other answer.
what about baseband?

C F is correct imo.
Remote connection and loading from server = PXE
Remote start up = Wake on LAN

A is not appropriate as hosts will not be deploying images, they will be loading them from server.
why not a and c

comments.content: I initially thought the same but then realized "must be started remotely" would mean Wake-on-Lan should be supported.
agreed, answer is A and F. PXE is a boot over the network but you still have to be present with the machine. Image deployment is remote.

questions.question_text: A technician is acquiring hardware devices and setting up a computer lab with virtual desktops. The lab computers must have the ability to connect automatically to the remote session upon boot and must be started remotely. Which of the following solutions must the hardware be able to support? (Choose two.)

A technician recently updated a printer driver on all the computers in an office. Shortly after the update, several users' accounts and passwords were compromised. Which of the following MOST likely explains the compromised accounts?

discussion.content: I would pick D more appropriate that a keylogger captured credentials via a Trojan Horse which could be the driver updated.

Bad question and answers to the question. What it may mean is all the computers received a Trojan Horse from downloading the driver update. The computers then became a botnet and credentials were sent out.

Selected Answer: D
keylogger is correct

Selected Answer: D
Why would a botnet compromise accounts and passwords? Keylogger is the only thing that has that capability, and was most likely installed in a fake driver that contained a trojan.

Selected Answer: D
I pick D because it makes sense that a keylogger was disguised as a print driver
SOME PEOPLE ARE JUST HERE TO SET CONFUSION - JUSTIFY THE CORRECT ANSWERS OR STFU

Selected Answer: D
D makes the most sense
Its because it's several user's accounts... so this is part of a botnet

"which explains the compromissed account?" refers to the current state of the accounts, I go for A. It doesn't ask what happened to the accounts. But I agree that the question could be asked in a better way. Because I have to assume they are part of a network, there is nothing mentioned about it.

What an awful question and answer options. If the driver contains a trojan then there are various possible ways to compromise data. Trojan should be the correct answer but...
With CompTIA questioning style I would expect them to reference high outbound network traffic if the correct answer was botnet (as they do in another question) therefore I will say keylogger. Another reason I believe keylogger to be correct is that this attack is stealing credentials (the primary purpose of a keylogger) while the primary purpose of a botnet is siphoning computing resources usually to create DDoS attacks or other illicit purposes (such as additional resources for cracking or bitcoin mining).
"All" was the keyword. All of the computers became apart of the botnet?

comments.content:
Updated a printer driver on "ALL" the computers
"SEVERAL" users's accounts and passwords were compromised

If it is botnet, should be all user's accounts and passwords were compromised instead several?
I go for keylogger

discussion.content:
Right and the antivirus definitions not being updated led to the supposed trojan horse with the possibility of a keylogger, which we don't even know if thats what really happened (keylogging). I will go with the antivirus, because it would prevent any of this, except for a zero-day attack, which is not a given possibility.

It asks what explains the situation, not what kind of potential attack occurred. Follow CompTIA's bullshit logic pertaining to other questions, and you can see what is going on here.

One thing we know for sure, this horse shit website is wrong again, as usual

This question is tricky. However, since keylogger needs users to type in in order for it to capture information, and in this case the username/passwords were compromised shortly after the update, and its not known if all users started using or typing in that soon. On the other hand, botnets are sometimes responsible for username/password compromise, so I think it is the possible answer.

comments.content: If you download a "driver" from third-party sites, you may actually be downloading a trojan. If a keylogger were installed along with the supposed drivers, all it takes is a screen unlock to enter credentials and capture them with the keylogger.
